headline: Opinion divided on proposed changes to media law in Kenya
author: patrick

breadcrumbs.name: Opinion divided on proposed changes to media law in Kenya

description: Chairman Kenya Correspondents Association (KCA). Oloo Janak. PHOTO/KCA By PATRICK MAYOYO Proposed amendments to the Media Council Act 2013 has sparked a heated debate among media and legal stakehol…
articleBody:
By PATRICK MAYOYO

Proposed amendments to the Media Council Act 2013 has sparked a heated debate among media and legal stakeholders with the two groups holding different views on the same.

Among the media stakeholders, the Kenya Correspondents Association (KCA) was the first to unleash a salvo against the proposed law saying the changes lacked public participation from stakeholders as is required by the law.

The KCA chairman Oloo Janak said his association had only learnt about the proposed changes when they were already before the National Assembly Committee on Communication, Information and Innovation.

“To the best of our recollection at KCA, no proposals have been tabled before the media stakeholders to debate or add on before they are/were taken to the National Assembly,” Mr Janak said in a statement.

However, lawyer William Oketch, the Chairman of the Media Council of Kenya (MCK) Complaints Commission played down concerns raised by KCA saying no stakeholders have been locked out from the process.

“Public participation takes place after the 1st reading when the Bill is committed to the Departmental committee to facilitate public participation,” he said.

Mr Oketch said having analysed the proposed changes; he can confidently assert that it is neither a threat nor affront to media freedoms.

“It just seeks to improve the regulatory framework by making it efficient and streamlined,” he asserted.

Mr Janak however said KCA was alarmed by the reported initiative to amend the Media Act quietly and called for clarification on who has initiated the process to amend the Act, what specific proposals have been made and why the industry has not been robustly involved.

“We urge stakeholders, at individual institutional levels not to fall into any temptation or conspiracy in a process so profound as the change of media laws. This direction must be avoided as it has the potential to drag the industry into controversy, bring disunity and disharmony, and which may lead to protracted legal action again, and in an election year,” he warned.

Mr Janak said the position of KCA was that, like in 2011-2013, the media industry and allied support groups must take a common position on this process and ensure open consultations and insist on public participation.

“Again, we must be alive to the dangers of initiating amendments to media laws in an election year because the state normally takes advantage of that to bring in provisions that are meant to undermine press freedom,” he warned.

The KCA chairman said reports of entrenched and self-serving interests and the possibility of advancing state zeal to control the media sector, through the amendment process ( the interests appear to be both in the media industry and within parliament) ‘are very unsettling and should worry us’.

“We at KCA look forward to any urgent response and clarification from any stakeholder group that may be a promoter or privy to this process, to inform our way forward. We will certainly not accept or participate in a flawed process,” Mr Janak noted.

However, Mr Oketch said from both a lawyer and adjudicator’s perspective, his preliminary pick-outs showed that the proposed changes does not take away from MCK nor add onto the Executive any functional roles and powers of the MCK under section 6.

He said the proposed amendments follows the British parliamentary model of Bill origination, Speakers approval for publication, 1st and 2nd reading, Committee stage, Report stage, 3rd reading and Assent.

“In this context the Bill has just been approved for publication then tabling after origination was done by the Chair of the Departmental committee due to emergent stakeholder concerns from previous engagements as far as 2018,” he added.

Mr Oketch said no stakeholders have been locked out from the process as public participation takes place after the 1st reading when the Bill is committed to the Departmental committee to facilitate public participation.

He said the National Assembly Committee on Communication, Information and Innovation will after Parliament resumes conduct public participation (by inviting views) comments from members of the public as well as inviting the core stakeholder groups to make presentations before it.

“The law binds them to take into consideration these views when making the report to the house,” he noted.

Mr Oketch said the proposed changes aims to heal some defects in the present as there are certain interpretative words which were already in the law but by omission the previous process failed to contextualize them for clarity and ease of regulatory efficiency in this way, media practitioners, consumer of media services and users of media services.

“This accords with regional and international best practices where due to convergence of platforms media practitioners or users need to be defined,” he emphasised.

Mr Oketch said having sat in the previous Media Complaints Commission plus as current chairperson this definition is a huge relief for adjudicatory reach.

“There are people in our newsrooms who are not journalist’s yet hold the microphone, practice this trade and continuously have breached the Code. When complaints come they are struck out on a technicality of the strict definition of a journalist to whom the Act applies. A great injustice to the aggrieved parties,” he noted.

Mr Oketch said the proposals streamlines the cadres of which journalists are within the accreditation ambit such as practitioners, local and foreign journalists, adding this is not a degrading of the original journalist’s standing but a matter of functional regulation akin to the Health Bill categorizing doctors, nurses, clinicians and lab technicians all as health/medical practitioners which in no way degrades a doctor’s eminent domain.

“The amendments attempt to widen the basket for Financing through a Levy and media fund. This seems a positive steps towards increasing alternative funding as government funds decrease in due course thus a move towards increased independence and autonomy,” he noted.

He added that the Bill entrenches the scope of regulatory for example; penalties for masquerading, in this way, those who are not accredited but practice illegally will be prosecuted hence weeding out quacks.

Mr Oketch observed that the Bill takes away from the ICT Cabinet Secretary powers of making regulations and places it in the Council with the scope or type of regulations expanded to include on financing, accreditation and regulation.

He said on the Complaints Commission the Bill deletes the section that qualified a sitting judicial officer from serving as chairperson as precautionary measure of independence plus relieving the Commission from the duty of serving process which ordinarily should be the complainants forte.

“The Bill then inserts the various interpretative/defined words the substantive sections across the entire Act to ensure ease of applicability,” he said.

On training and approval of curriculum for journalism schools, Mr Oketch said the Bill attempts to entrench the role of the Media Council of Kenya in determining training curriculum.

“A good move for streamlining standards. But if not amended it’s headed for turbulent waters. There are several High Court decisions affirming that the Commission for University Education is the only body that approves training curriculum,” he warned.

He added that this case was a contest between the Council for Legal Education (CLE) and CUE. The CLE lost noting that the best way would be to amend the section and include the phrase,’ “In consultation with the Commission for University Education,”

headline: Journalist Gatonye was strangled to death, autopsy reveals
author: patrick

breadcrumbs.name: Journalist Gatonye was strangled to death, autopsy reveals

description: The founder and editor of online science journal Rocket Science Gatonye Gathura. PHOTO/COURTESY By ABDULHAKIM SHERMAN Science journalist Gatonye Gathura was killed through strangulation a post mort…
articleBody:
By ABDULHAKIM SHERMAN

Science journalist Gatonye Gathura was killed through strangulation a post mortem conducted on the body has revealed.

The postmortem conducted at Naivasha sub-county hospital mortuary by Dr Titus Ngulungu revealed that Gatonye who was the founder and editor of online science journal Rocket Science, was strangled using a computer charging cable and was hit on the back of his head with a blunt object.

According to Dr Ngulungu, a government pathologist, Gatonye died from lack of air after the killers used the wire to strangle him.

“The report clearly indicates that the victim was murdered using a wire and there is an injury at the back of the head inflicted by a blunt object,” he said.

He added that the body could have stayed for up to one week on the scene before it was found by members of the public and collected by police.

The family of the health and science writer who were at the mortuary called for justice. They said he would be laid to rest on Thursday at the family’s home in Limuru.

The Kenya Editor’s Guild has demanded for speedy investigations into the scribe’s death including an inquest.

The Kenya Editor’s Guild President Churchill Otieno, said speedy investigations were required to establish the cause of death and shed light on the circumstances surrounding Gatonye’s death including conducting an inquest.

Detectives have revealed that the veteran journalist was in possession of land files and intended to write an expose before his death.

Preliminary investigations conducted by detectives from the Directorate of Criminal Investigations (DCI) indicate that the expose would have shed light on a land dispute in the Ewaso Kedong area, a border between Narok and Nakuru Counties.

DCI investigators are now probing the matter to establish whether the expose is directly connected to his death and whether some individuals were out to silence him.

The journalist’s body was found at the Naivasha Sub County Referral Hospital mortuary, a month after he went missing. This is after the Registrar of Persons took finger prints of the decomposed body.

A copper wire was found on his neck, an indication that he had been tortured before he met his death.

articleBody:
Juventus talisman Cristiano Ronaldo. PHOTO/JUVENTUS FC

By AGENCIES

35-year-old Portuguese football sensation Cristiano Ronaldo has set two more goal-scoring records.

He achieved his latest feat in the win over Lazio on Monday. When he bagged a brace in the clash with Juve’s title rivals, who have fallen off the pace since the restart.

Indeed at one stage in the match Ronaldo even jumped ahead of Lazio’s Ciro Immobile in the Serie A top scoring charts, only until the Italian’s late penalty drew them level for the season.

Yet Ronaldo had already made history by then, having become the first player to rack up 50 or more goals in not just Serie A, but in La Liga and the Premier League, too.

What’s more, Ronaldo is the fastest player to hit half a century in the whole of Serie A history – taking just 61 matches to reach the impressive tally.

According to Mirror Ronaldo beat AC Milan legend Andriy Shevchenko to the total by a clear seven games, while namesake Brazilian icon Ronaldo took 70 fixtures during his time with Inter Milan.

Milan legend Andriy Shevchenko to the total by a clear seven games, while namesake Brazilian icon Ronaldo took 70 fixtures during his time with Inter Milan.

The Juventus talisman reached the milestone with a penalty of his own, placing the ball into the bottom right corner to open the scoring after 51 minutes.

Immobile’s spot kick led to a some nervy final moments for Juventus, but they stood firm to leave them needing just two wins from their last four games.

Next up is a trip to Udinese on Thursday, followed by the visit of Sampdoria on Sunday.

In the meantime closest rivals Inter welcome Fiorentina on Tuesday ahead of their away clash at Genoa on Saturday.

headline: 193 countries adopt the first global agreement on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence
author: patrick

breadcrumbs.name: 193 countries adopt the first global agreement on the Ethics of Artificial...

description: More mass-market consumer applications are expected with the development of what is known as ‘assistive technologies’. PHOTO/PEXELS By SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT All member states of the UN …
articleBody:
By SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT

All member states of the UN Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) have adopted a historical text that defines the common values and principles needed to ensure the healthy development of Artificial Intelligence (AI).

Artificial intelligence is present in everyday life, from booking flights and applying for loans to steering driverless cars. It is also used in specialized fields such as cancer screening or to help create inclusive environments for the disabled.

According to UNESCO, AI is also supporting the decision-making of governments and the private sector, as well as helping combat global problems such as climate change and world hunger.

However, the agency warns that the technology ‘is bringing unprecedented challenges’.

“ We see increased gender and ethnic bias, significant threats to privacy, dignity and agency, dangers of mass surveillance, and increased use of unreliable AI technologies in law enforcement, to name a few. Until now, there were no universal standards to provide an answer to these issues”, UNESCO explained in a statement.

Considering this, the adopted text aims to guide the construction of the necessary legal infrastructure to ensure the ethical development of this technology.

“The world needs rules for artificial intelligence to benefit humanity. The Recommendation on the ethics of AI is a major answer. It sets the first global normative framework while giving States the responsibility to apply it at their level. UNESCO will support its 193 Member States in its implementation and ask them to report regularly on their progress and practices”, said Audrey Azoulay, UNESCO chief.

The text aims to highlight the advantages of AI, while reducing the risks it also entails. According to the agency, it provides a guide to ensure that digital transformations promote human rights and contribute to the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals, addressing issues around transparency, accountability and privacy, with action-oriented policy chapters on data governance, education, culture, labour, healthcare and the economy.

One of its main calls is to protect data, going beyond what tech firms and governments are doing to guarantee individuals more protection by ensuring transparency, agency and control over their personal data. The Recommendation also explicitly bans the use of AI systems for social scoring and mass surveillance.

The text also emphasises that AI actors should favour data, energy and resource-efficient methods that will help ensure that AI becomes a more prominent tool in the fight against climate change and in tackling environmental issues.

“Decisions impacting millions of people should be fair, transparent and contestable. These new technologies must help us address the major challenges in our world today, such as increased inequalities and the environmental crisis, and not deepening them.” said Gabriela Ramos, UNESCO’s Assistant Director General for Social and Human Sciences.

You can read the full text here.

headline: Rights experts call for end to violence against women in Tigray conflict
author: patrick

breadcrumbs.name: Rights experts call for end to violence against women in Tigray conflict

description: A woman holds a message which says “relief” in Tigrinya during an exercise at a safe house in Tigray, Ethiopia. PHOTO/PAULA SEIJO/UNFPA By ABDULHAKIM SHERMAN Experts appointed by the UN…
articleBody:
A woman holds a message which says “relief” in Tigrinya during an exercise at a safe house in Tigray, Ethiopia. PHOTO/PAULA SEIJO/UNFPA

By ABDULHAKIM SHERMAN

Experts appointed by the UN Human Rights Council have called for urgent action to end violence against women and girls caught in the Tigray conflict in northern Ethiopia.

In a statement, they expressed grave concern about the widespread sexual and gender-based violence attributed to Ethiopian, Eritrean, Tigray and Amhara forces, as well as allied militia.

These incidents constitute some of the most egregious violations of human rights and humanitarian law, according to the experts.

“They appear to have been used as part of a deliberate strategy to terrorize, degrade and humiliate the victims and the ethnic minority group that they belong to with acquiescence of the State and non-State actors’ parties to the conflict,” they said.

The experts added that the brutal acts have devastating physical and psychological impacts on the victims, which are exacerbated by the lack of access to assistance, support and redress for survivors.

The UN continues to voice alarm over the war in Tigray, which began just over a year ago. Last month, the UN Human Rights High Commissioner, Michelle Bachelet, noted that the conflict has been marked by “extreme brutality”.

The rights experts said although the exact prevalence of gender-based violence is unknown, estimates are shocking.

From November 2020 through June of this year, some 2,204 survivors reported sexual violence to health facilities across the Tigray region.

Furthermore, one of the one-stop centres reported that the majority of victims, or 90 per cent, were underage girls, and estimated that visits have quadrupled since the conflict began.

“Despite the humanitarian situation, proper access to facilities is vital to ensure adequate care, for instance for women and girls at risk of developing life-threatening infections, or to allow for abortion for women and girls who become pregnant as a result of rape,” they stressed.

UN experts express grave concern for widespread sexual and gender-based violence committed against women and girls in Trigray conflict in Ethiopia. PHOTO/UN

However, the experts said these figures are an underestimation of the true extent of gender-based violence being committed. Cases are severely under-reported due to fear, stigma and inability to access health or support centres.

Displaced women vulnerable

The experts reported that the violence occurred in both rural and urban areas, in the victims’ homes or in places where they were sheltering.

In some cases, women and girls were raped because of their perceived or actual political affiliation, to pressure them to reveal the whereabouts of their male relatives, or as acts of revenge.

“Internally displaced women and girls in Ethiopia, and Eritrean refugee women and girls living in the Tigray region, have been particularly exposed to sexual violence. Eritrean women and girls, specifically, have been seriously affected by the conflict and doubly victimized,” the experts said.

The experts noted that in addition to the grave consequences of sexual violence, most victims have also been harmed in other ways by the conflict including by having close relatives killed.

Role of UN experts

The UN experts reminded parties to the conflict of their duty to respect and protect human rights, and to prevent violations in any territory under their control.

They also urged the sides to implement recommendations contained in a joint report by the Ethiopian Human Rights Office and its UN counterpart.

The 14 experts who issued the statement receive their mandates from the UN Human Rights Council, which is based in Geneva.

They monitor specific country situations or thematic issues, such as violence against women, discrimination against women and girls, and the rights of internally displaced persons.

The experts are independent of the UN and serve in their individual capacity. As such, they are not UN staff, nor are they paid by the Organization.

articleBody:
Portuguese football megastar Cristiano Ronaldo. PHOTO/JUVENTUS FC

BY AGENCIES

Portuguese football megastar Cristiano Ronaldo will be placed in quarantine for two weeks after the Juventus footballer returned to Turin.

The Portuguese attacker spent almost two months in his native Madeira as the coronavirus pandemic struck Italy, forcing the country into lockdown.

Ronaldo was expected back on May 18, when clubs were initially scheduled to return to training.

The Italian government moved that date forward to May 4 after many regions gave permission for training centres to open again, prompting Juventus to recall the foreign players who had left the country as the Covid-19 situation grew worse.

The players coming back will have to undergo two weeks of quarantine upon their arrival in Italy before they can begin training again.

While Ronaldo, 35, and his family were on the way back to Turin, many of his team-mates were being tested for coronavirus at the Juventus Training Centre.

Cristiano Ronaldo closing in on another goal record in Italy when Serie A resumes. PHOTO/EPA

Aaron Ramsey, Federico Bernardeschi, Juan Cuadrado, Carlo Pinsoglio and Merih Demiral, who is recovering from injury, were all examined.

As of Tuesday, training will resume but players will have to work on their own to abide by social distancing rules.

Despite the government’s decision to lift restrictions on athletes of team sports returning to training, the nation’s Sports Minister, Vincenzo Spadafora, said there is “no way” football can return soon.

Although there have been fears that the government could ban some sports for several months, Italian Football Federation (FIGC) president Gabriele Gravina has warned that such a move “would be the death of Italian football”, while Lazio sporting director Igli Tare said clubs are willing to wait several months before resuming the season.

“I heard that the order could come from the Minister of Sport this week,” he said. “But that would not be within his remit. FIFA, UEFA and FIGC have explained that the leagues must be finished within the calendar year.

“If we don’t start the league again in June, we will do it when it’s possible.”

headline: Kenyan editors demand thorough investigations into deaths of journalists
author: patrick

breadcrumbs.name: Kenyan editors demand thorough investigations into deaths of journalists

description: A drawing of former Standard Group cartoonist Joshua Nanjero, who was found dead at his home in Kayole, Nairobi on November 23. CARTOON/GAMZZ By ABDULKARIM SHERMAN The Kenya Editor’s Guild has aske…
articleBody:
By ABDULKARIM SHERMAN

The Kenya Editor’s Guild has asked government investigative agencies to conduct a speedy probe into the deaths of two journalists.

The Kenya Editor’s Guild President Churchill Otieno, asked government investigative agencies to speedily investigate the death of science journalist Gathonye Gathura and cartoonist Joshua Nanjero.

“The Kenya Editors Guild commits to remain steadfast in doing everything possible to establish the circumstances surrounding the two deaths,” Mr Otieno said.

The KEG President said speedy investigations were required to establish the cause of death and shed light on the circumstances surrounding the deaths by conducting postmortems and inquests.

Science journalist and founder of online science journal Rocket Science, Gatonye Gathura, was found dead on Thursday.

The body of Mr Gathura who went missing on October 26, 2021, was traced to Naivasha Sub-County Referral Hospital morgue after it was booked there as “unknown male adult”.

Naivasha Sub-County Police Commander Samuel Waweru said they were treating the death as a murder case.

“We are treating his death as murder. We suspect he was killed elsewhere and the body dumped in Naivasha,” Waweru told The Standard.

Police say Gathura’s body was initially found dumped on the Naivasha-Mai Mahiu Road on the day he was reported missing.

The Registrar of Persons is said to have positively identified the body of Gathura today using finger prints.

Standard Group cartoonist Joshua Nanjero, was found dead at his home in Kayole, Nairobi on November 23.

Standard newspaper says a postmortem report showed he had a clot in his brain, and his lungs had collapsed.

Gathura’s death brings to 11 the number of journalists in Kenya who have either gone missing or were found dead under mysterious circumstances. Most of the deaths remain unresolved.

A former Nation Media Group editor, Dan Otieno, died in a hit-and-run road accident in November 2020 along Waiyaki Way near Uthiru stage in Kiambu County. Nobody has been arrested in connection with that accident.

Nobody has ever been charged over Kariuki’s death. Mr Kariuki was then working at the Office of the Deputy President.

Today the murder of Kenya Broadcasting Corporation (KBC) senior editor, Betty Barasa, in her house in Oloolua Ngong on the night of April 7 still remains unresolved.

The whereabouts of Dickson Bosire, popularly known as Bogonko Bosire, the founder of Jackal News and former Nation Media Group legal editor, Albert Muriuki, who disappeared sometime around 2013 remain unknown to date.

Other cases includes that of veteran journalist and founder of Mirror Weekly John Kituyi who was walking home from work near his home in Eldoret town when he was killed by unknown people and freelance photographer Dennis Otieno who was gunned down by three men seeking to recover from him a ‘sensitive’ photo he had taken earlier in the day in Kitale in 2016.

During celebrations to mark the International Day to End Impunity and Crimes Against Journalists (IDEA), UNESCO said between 2006 and 2020, more than 1,200 journalists were killed because of their work and nine out of 10 cases, the killers go unpunished.

The UN notes that while journalists killings are the most extreme form of media censorship, journalists are also subjected to countless threats – ranging from kidnapping, torture and other physical attacks to harassment, particularly in the digital sphere.

UNESCO adds that in many cases, threats of violence and attacks against journalists are not properly investigated. This impunity emboldens the perpetrators of the crimes and at the same time has a chilling effect on society, including journalists themselves.

There is also the unresolved cases of former Standard Group Kilifi correspondent Joseph Masha, who collapsed and died moments after meeting a politician, former Weekly Citizen journalist Francis Nyaruri who in 2009 his decapitated body was found two weeks after he disappeared among other cases.

headline: Want to put together a winning AFCON team? Here’s the formula
author: admin

breadcrumbs.name: Want to put together a winning AFCON team? Here’s the formula

description: Senegal’s Sadio Mane during the 2019 AFCON final soccer match between Algeria and Senegal in Cairo. He also plays for Liverpool. PHOTO/EPA-EFE/KHALED ELFIQI By Ernest Yeboah Acheampong and  El…
articleBody:
Senegal’s Sadio Mane during the 2019 AFCON final soccer match between Algeria and Senegal in Cairo. He also plays for Liverpool. PHOTO/EPA-EFE/KHALED ELFIQI

By Ernest Yeboah Acheampong

The African Cup of Nations (AFCON) tournament is the most important sporting event on the continent. It attracts media attention, sponsors and draws significant global viewership. Organised every two years, it is also considered one of the most difficult to win based on a large qualification pool.

Since it was first held in 1957, only 14 countries have won the right to be called African champions. What factors could possibly explain this?

There is a shortage of research in this area. So, we set out to understand what factors could explain the successful performance of these national teams in Africa’s premier football tournament.

Unlike normal clubs, national teams don’t have full-time players. Instead they have to draw them from club teams, both domestically and abroad. Given the short time they have available to select and prepare a national team for a major tournament, a huge plus would be knowing what a winning combination looks like. Understanding these factors could also have broader management applications, such as a reliance on teamwork, cohesion, diversity as well as recruiting the right people.

Drawing panel data from AFCON tournaments held between 1990 and 2017, we studied the performance of 38 African countries. We found that team mix, young talent, team experience and the national team’s ranking by FIFA had a significant marginal effect on the performance of teams in the continent’s premier tournament.

Our data analysis showed how active, elite foreign based and local players, a blend of young talents, team experience and familiarity with the terrain and nature of the tournament, and consistent high international ranking by international football governing body FIFA improved a team’s chances of winning tournaments.

Based on our findings we have come up with a proposed framework for composing a national team around four areas: team mix, young talent, team experience and international rankings. This framework applies even at the World Cup level to teams from other regions.

So, what is it about these dimensions of team composition that explains a national team’s chances of winning the African Cup of Nations?

First, a look at selecting players who have played for top leagues abroad.

Team mix: players from foreign and local leagues

These players offer experience that translates into high performance. Foreign clubs have better training facilities which enable migrant players to develop their talents and improve their performance.

But players from national teams bring their own set of strengths. Those who have played in a domestic league are familiar with the African terrain and adapt better to terrain changes.

There’s more to the team mix than this: a national team increases its winning chances if it can establish a unique identity that transcends the assembly of star players.

And then there’s the age factor. The consideration of what we label young talent is also imperative to overall success. This refers to a team’s average age. A team with an average age of 22 can be described as youthful. These players offer physical strength but they are inexperienced. A mature team is one with an average age of 26. These players have strength and stamina to ensure high performance. The third category in the mix is the experienced group, built around players aged 27 years and older. This category has experience but may lack strength on the pitch.

Ideally, a team should have a blend of all three.

Team experience is also crucial. This refers to the number of appearances made in the tournament, which can help guarantee familiarity with tournaments. A good level of team experience is participating on average at least nine times. Beyond this, a team stands an improved chance of thriving in continental tournaments.

The fact that team experience matters is supported by other studies that have found a similar outcome of experience which tends to affect performance.

FIFA rankings also matter. Highly ranked teams have better medal winning potential in tournaments than lower ranked teams. FIFA ranking is a strong determinant to grouping national teams for tournaments. This ensures that these teams are seeded in international competitions due to their sporting success.

The danger is that high rankings lead to complacency which in turn can ruin a team’s potential.

We also identified an added ingredient: a team’s ability to integrate individual talent within the limited time available for preparation increased the likelihood of a better performance in the tournament.

A good balanced team

Our framework for a national team’s composition provides useful information on elements to consider when putting together a national team. This formula can be used by team managers, performance analysts and match pundits. Our framework does not shoot down the role of motivation in team performance but points to a neglected area – team composition.

A team composed of more professional players from elite leagues abroad provides a good balanced team capable of achieving desirable results. This new discovery contributes to theory and practice alongside the concepts of teamwork, team building and diversity to achieve performance goals.

headline: Tiny village in Kenya using mushroom farming to fight climate change
author: patrick

breadcrumbs.name: Tiny village in Kenya using mushroom farming to fight climate change

description: Two ladies tendering their crops inside Lari Forest as part of the Plantations Establishment and Livelihood Improvement Scheme (PELIS). PHOTO/ROBERT WANYONYI By PATRICK MAYOYO Before they embraced …
articleBody:
By PATRICK MAYOYO

Before they embraced mushroom farming, some members of Uplands Mushroom Growers in Lari, Kiambu County, regarded it as wild crop with no economic, nutritional or health benefits.

Majority of them had grown up seeing mushrooms sprout up in the local fields and woodlands but they were cautioned against touching them leave alone eating as they were regarded as a poisonous plants by their parents.

“While growing up here in Lari we were rebuked by our parents whenever we played with mushrooms we had picked in the fields warning us that makuno – Kikuyu name for mushrooms, was poison,” Anne Wanjiru a resident of Lari says.

But today, their story has changed. Thanks to the introduction of the Green Zones Development Support Project II (GZDSPII) that is funded by the African Development Bank at a tune of Ksh 5 billion, that is now helping them change their lives through mushrooms farming.

Their organization Uplands Mushroom Growers is now spearheading a revolutionary social economic campaign of not only training villagers on how to grow mushrooms but also creating awareness on how to help fight deforestation, climate change and its impacts and sustainably benefit from the initiative.

Between 1980 and 2000, Kenya lost nearly 50 percent of its forest cover. Some 300,000 hectares of forest were destroyed due to intensive logging, charcoal production and large-scale clearance of wooded areas for tea plantations.

Symbolic of this destruction is the Mau Forest, at 273,000 hectares the largest forested area in Kenya with a seven-lake drainage basin covering more than 69,000 km 2, from which one quarter of its canopy had disappeared.

The project is also expected to significantly increase (by 25%) the annual incomes of 375,912 households (40% female-headed) through direct employment, and income generating activities.

And as farmers in Lari, Kiambu in Central Kenya continue to experience dismal crop yields due to changing weather patterns triggered by the impacts of climate change mainly due to deforestation, Uplands Mushroom Growers are now conserving local forests through afforestation as they also engage in mushroom farming.

According to, Mr David Kuria, the Deputy Project Manager of GZDSP II, the project provides new and more efficient ways of increasing forest cover, increasing food security and improving community livelihoods through sustainable and inclusive commodity value chain and market development.

Mr Kuria adds that the project is being implemented in 15 counties in Kenya namely; Embu, Meru, Machakos, Tharaka-Nithi, Nyeri, Murang’a, Kirinyaga, Kiambu, Nyandarua, Nakuru, Baringo, Kericho, Bomet, Nyamira and Kisii.

“These counties cover four forest conservancies and three out of five of Kenya’s water towers including Mt. Kenya, Aberdares, and the Mau complex. The counties were selected based on levels of forest degradation, social economic and environmental vulnerability,” Mr Kuria said.

He added that the project, which will be implemented over a period of six years (2018-2024), comprises three main components, Forest Conservation and Livelihood Support, Sustainable and Inclusive Value Chains Development and Project Management and Coordination.

Tony Njuguna, a comedian and retired advertising executive is among residents of Lari who has embraced mushroom farming.

“When I was informed about this project I decided to give it a try and I can now say that I made the right decision. I just harvested my first crop and I am not complaining,” he said when we visited his project.

Njuguna said he had not only decided to expand the mushroom business but he had invested in the required expertise through training and engaging consultants to ensure his production processes are purely organic.

“We are using vermiculture technique to avoid use of pesticides in the production of our mushrooms which makes them purely organic,” he says.

Vermiculture is a technique based on utilizing some species of earthworms to convert organic waste into vermicompost which is again, the product of decomposition by various worms. It is a practice of harvesting worms that take part in decomposing organic waste and turning it into nutrient-rich fertilizer.

For farmers who have already embraced mushroom farming like Tony, the future looks bright. Currently, Kenya produces 40 tonnes of mushrooms and imports another 17 tonnes from Rwanda to meet its demand.

Studies show the global mushroom market was valued at 12.74 million tons (MT) in 2018 and is projected to reach 20.84 million tons (MT) by 2026, exhibiting a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 6.41 percent in the forecast period.

The Global “Functional Mushroom Market” 2021 report shows that the global mushroom market size is expected to reach US$ 95.24 billion by 2028, expanding at a CAGR of 9.5 percent.

IMAGE/FAO

Mr Patrick Kanyi Muchiri, a senior technician at the Institute of Biotechnology at the Jomo Kenyatta University of Science and Technology (JKUAT) says mushroom farming helps in recycling of agricultural waste.

“Spawn the raw material used in growing mushrooms that mainly comes from agricultural waste like maize husks, rice and wheat straws and saw dust makes mushroom farming friendly to the environment as the resultant compost can be used as fertilizer to grow other crops in the nearby farms,” Muchiri adds.

There’s a growing body of evidence of how mushrooms can help the environment. In a 2008 TED talk, mycologist Paul Stamets discussed six ways the mycelium fungus can help save the planet, including cleaning polluted soil, making insecticides, treating smallpox and even flu viruses.

Researchers also found that a naturally occurring bacterium that occurs from harvesting mushrooms can actually be turned into a biofuel, which can reduce emissions from biofuels, according to a study in the journal Science Advances.

IMAGE/FAO

Mushrooms are even a solution for packaging. The New York-based biotech company Ecovative Design, for instance, has made packaging material which has been used by companies such as Ikea and Dell, according to NBC News.

Mr Basil Murila, the Gender and Community Development Officer for the Green Zones Development Support Project II GZDSP II says apart from mushroom farming, the project supports 45 groups to implement income generating projects.

“The project is focused on fish-farming, sheep breeding, briquettes, banana value addition, events hosting, dairy and goat farming, water-harvesting, eco-tourism, virgin forest soil harvesting and herbal medicines,” he said.

Mr Murila said the groups are composed of between 15 to 30 people and they are spread out in all the 15 counties where the GZDSP II is being implemented.

He adds that projects like the Uplands Mushroom Growers being implemented through the Plantations Establishment and Livelihood Improvement Scheme Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

Mushrooms are filamentous fungi that produce large, often edible fruiting bodies. They live on organic material, thriving on compost, fallen leaves and damp wood and any other dead plant or animal matter. Their role in causing decay is important in maintaining ecological cycles.

The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) says studies estimate that the total number of useful fungi – defined as having edible and medicinal value – are over 2 300 species adding that cultivated mushrooms have now become popular all over the world.

FAO in a booklet called Make Money By Growing Mushrooms adds that mushroom cultivation can directly improve livelihoods through economic, nutritional and medicinal contributions.

“Medicinal fungi have routinely been used in traditional Chinese medicine. Today, an estimated six percent of edible mushrooms are known to have medicinal properties and can be found in health tonics, tinctures, teas, soups and herbal formulas,” FAO notes.

Studies show fungi also play an important role in the carbon cycle, the biogeochemical process by which carbon—the essential element of life on Earth—moves between the air, soils and water. Plants sequester carbon dioxide, but when they die, that carbon enters the soil—a lot of it.

Globally, soil is the biggest single terrestial reservoir of carbon, far more than the amount of carbon contained in living things and in the atmosphere combined.

The rate at which that carbon leaves the soil can obviously have a major impact on the amount of carbon in the atmosphere, which in turn helps drive climate change.

Without fungi we wouldn’t have antibiotics, blue cheeses and most importantly, beer.

Mr Mwaura Kamau, the secretary of Uplands Mushroom Growers, says their group is helping in mitigating against impacts of climate change as they are involved in afforestation activities.

A report titled, “” says mushroom cultivation market accounted for a value of US$ 16.7 billion in 2020.

The report adds that global mushroom cultivation market is projected to witness significant growth due to factors such as the multiple health benefits of mushrooms, increasing per capita mushroom consumption, cost-effective production and rising demand for vegan and natural food in the diet and increasing health-conscious population across the globe.

However, it notes that the lack of technical knowledge for spawn production among growers in developing countries can hinder the growth of the market.

A 2009 study by the Rural Infrastructure and Agro-Industries Division of UN’s Food and Agriculture organization says mushroom cultivation can directly improve livelihoods through economic, nutritional and medicinal contributions.

The study shows that mushrooms both add flavour to bland staple foods and are a valuable food in their own right: they are often considered to provide a fair substitute for meat, with at least a comparable nutritional value to many vegetables.

“The consumption of mushrooms can make a valuable addition to the often unbalanced diets of people in developing countries. Fresh mushrooms have a high water content, around 90 percent, so drying them is an effective way to both prolong their shelf-life and preserve their flavour and nutrients,” the report notes.

It adds that mushroom cultivation activities can play an important role in supporting the local economy by contributing to subsistence food security, nutrition, and medicine; generating additional employment and income through local, regional and national trade; and offering opportunities for processing enterprises.

Another study, , by Prof. Nezir Tanović, says all indicators are in favour of the fact that there is a gradual increase in the mushroom production volumes.

“The volume refers not only to the production of button mushrooms, but also to production of oyster and shiitake mushrooms,” the UNDP study says.

IMAGE/UGC

For anyone still doubting the potential of farming in creating wealth, the President of the African Development Bank (ADB), Dr. Akinwumi Adesina says by 2030, the size of the food and agri-business in Africa will reach $1 Trillion and if one was thinking of how to make money, this is the sector to be in.

Before they embraced mushroom farming, some members of Uplands Mushroom Growers in Lari, Kiambu County, regarded it as wild crop with no economic, nutritional or health benefits.

Majority of them had grown up seeing mushrooms sprout up in the local fields and woodlands but they were cautioned against touching them leave alone eating as they were regarded as a poisonous plants by their parents.

“While growing up here in Lari we were rebuked by our parents whenever we played with mushrooms we had picked in the fields warning us that makuno – Kikuyu name for mushrooms, was poison,” Anne Wanjiru a resident of Lari says.

But today, their story has changed. Thanks to the introduction of the Green Zones Development Support Project II (GZDSPII) that is funded by the African Development Bank at a tune of Ksh 5 billion, that is now helping them change their lives through mushrooms farming.

Their organization Uplands Mushroom Growers is now spearheading a revolutionary social economic campaign of not only training villagers on how to grow mushrooms but also creating awareness on how to help fight deforestation, climate change and its impacts and sustainably benefit from the initiative.

Between 1980 and 2000, Kenya lost nearly 50 percent of its forest cover. Some 300,000 hectares of forest were destroyed due to intensive logging, charcoal production and large-scale clearance of wooded areas for tea plantations.

Symbolic of this destruction is the Mau Forest, at 273,000 hectares the largest forested area in Kenya with a seven-lake drainage basin covering more than 69,000 km2, from which one quarter of its canopy had disappeared.

The project is also expected to significantly increase (by 25%) the annual incomes of 375,912 households (40% female-headed) through direct employment, and income generating activities.

And as farmers in Lari, Kiambu in Central Kenya continue to experience dismal crop yields due to changing weather patterns triggered by the impacts of climate change mainly due to deforestation, Uplands Mushroom Growers are now conserving local forests through afforestation as they also engage in mushroom farming.

According to, Mr David Kuria, the Deputy Project Manager of GZDSP II, the project provides new and more efficient ways of increasing forest cover, increasing food security and improving community livelihoods through sustainable and inclusive commodity value chain and market development.

Mr Kuria adds that the project is being implemented in 15 counties in Kenya namely; Embu, Meru, Machakos, Tharaka-Nithi, Nyeri, Murang’a, Kirinyaga, Kiambu, Nyandarua, Nakuru, Baringo, Kericho, Bomet, Nyamira and Kisii.

“These counties cover four forest conservancies and three out of five of  Kenya’s water towers including Mt. Kenya, Aberdares, and the Mau complex. The counties were selected based on levels of forest degradation, social economic and environmental vulnerability,” Mr Kuria said.

He added that the project, which will be implemented over a period of six years (2018-2024), comprises three main components, Forest Conservation and Livelihood Support, Sustainable and Inclusive Value Chains Development and Project Management and Coordination.

Tony Njuguna, a comedian and retired advertising executive is among residents of Lari who has embraced mushroom farming.

“When I was informed about this project I decided to give it a try and I can now say that I made the right decision. I just harvested my first crop and I am not complaining,” he said when we visited his project.

Njuguna said he had not only decided to expand the mushroom business but he had invested in the required expertise through training and engaging consultants to ensure his production processes are purely organic.

“We are using vermiculture technique to avoid use of pesticides in the production of our mushrooms which makes them purely organic,” he says.

Vermiculture is a technique based on utilizing some species of earthworms to convert organic waste into vermicompost which is again, the product of decomposition by various worms. It is a practice of harvesting worms that take part in decomposing organic waste and turning it into nutrient-rich fertilizer.

For farmers who have already embraced mushroom farming like Tony, the future looks bright. Currently, Kenya produces 40 tonnes of mushrooms and imports another 17 tonnes from Rwanda to meet its demand.

Studies show the global mushroom market was valued at 12.74 million tons (MT) in 2018 and is projected to reach 20.84 million tons (MT) by 2026, exhibiting a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 6.41 percent in the forecast period.

“Spawn the raw material used in growing mushrooms that mainly comes from agricultural waste like maize husks, rice and wheat straws and saw dust makes mushroom farming friendly to the environment as the resultant compost can be used as fertilizer to grow other crops in the nearby farms,” Muchiri adds.

There’s a growing body of evidence of how mushrooms can help the environment. In a 2008 TED talk, mycologist Paul Stamets discussed six ways the mycelium fungus can help save the planet, including cleaning polluted soil, making insecticides, treating smallpox and even flu viruses.

Researchers also found that a naturally occurring bacterium that occurs from harvesting mushrooms can actually be turned into a biofuel, which can reduce emissions from biofuels, according to a study in the journal Science Advances.

Mushrooms are even a solution for packaging. The New York-based biotech company Ecovative Design, for instance, has made packaging material which has been used by companies such as Ikea and Dell, according to NBC News.

“Medicinal fungi have routinely been used in traditional Chinese medicine. Today, an estimated six percent of edible mushrooms are known to have medicinal properties and can be found in health tonics, tinctures, teas, soups and herbal formulas,” FAO notes.

headline: UN Women: Violence against women now a global crisis
author: ABDULHAKIM SHERMAN

breadcrumbs.name: UN Women: Violence against women now a global crisis

articleBody:
Young girls campaign to end violence against women and girls in El Salvador. PHOTO/UNICEF

Violence against women is now a global crisis, the Under-Secretary-General of the United Nations and Executive Director of UN Women, Ms Sima Bahous, has said.

Ms Bahous who was speaking during the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women celebrated on November 25 said more than 70 per cent of women have experienced gender-based violence in some crisis settings adding in countries, both rich and poor, gender prejudice has fuelled acts of violence toward women and girls.

“Here at the UN, and across the world, we are celebrating those who are working to protect women and girls and defend their human rights,” she said.

Ms Bahous said UN Women welcomed new partners — governments, non-governmental organizations, institutions, community groups, people everywhere — to join and raise their voices and work together to transform lives, not only during the 16 Days of Activism, but every day.

“In all of our own neighbourhoods, there are women and girls living in danger. Around the world, conflict, climate-related natural disasters, food insecurity and human rights violations are exacerbating violence against women,” she noted.

Ms Bahous said violence against women often goes unreported, silenced by stigma, shame, fear of the perpetrators and fear of a justice system that does not work for women.

The UN Women Executive Director said the COVID-19 pandemic, with all its isolation and distancing, has enabled unseen violence: a second, shadow pandemic of violence against women and girls, where they often found themselves in lockdown with their abusers.

“In all corners of the world, helplines for violence against women saw an increase in reports,” she observed.

Ms Bahous said the human rights of women — including the right to security, dignity, equality and justice — are core principles of international law and the leadership and safety of women, in all their diversity, plays a vital role in economic progress, community welfare, children’s health and education, and more.

“All human life benefits when women’s human rights are upheld, and we all suffer when those rights are abused,” she reiterated.

She however noted that there is hope as in recent years, much has been much achieved to prevent and reduce violence against women and girls noting that the challenge now is to expand global efforts and make a difference in more lives.

“We must ensure that essential services are available and accessible to women of all ages. We need to support environments, online and off, in which women can participate safely in decision-making,” she said.

Ms Bahous revealed that new opportunities are opening as last summer, as more than USD 40 billion was committed to the rights of women and girls around the world when the Generation Equality Forum launched the Action Coalition on Gender-based Violence.

The Coalition brings together a wide array of women’s groups and others: youth, civil society, faith-based institutions, philanthropy, private sector, international organizations and UN Member States.

Ms Bahous said the International Day for the Elimination of Violence also opens some exciting hopes as it begins the annual “16 Days against Gender-Based Violence,” a series of events aimed at creating real change.

She added that for 2021, the theme is, “Orange the World: End Violence Against Women Now!”. “Orange” symbolizes a brighter future, free of violence. I welcome and urge you to participate.

She praised women’s groups and other concerned people around the world saying they have been vital to the progress that has been made.

“Going forward, together, we can make life better and brighter for many more girls and women across the world,” Ms Bahous noted.

The UN refugee agency, (UNHCR) says one in five refugee or internally displaced women have faced sexual violence, and the situation continues to worsen globally.

“A lethal mix of confinement, deepening poverty and economic duress is unleashing a renewed wave of violence against refugee, displaced and stateless women and girls”, UNHCR said in a statement.

To tackle the crisis, the UN agency has called for funding to be scaled up for grassroots projects that focus on prevention and helping victims of gender-based violence.

By ABDULHAKIM SHERMAN

Kenyans took to social media to express their shock at revelations that Kenyan celebrated referee Aden Marwa has been caught in a sting football corruption operation by Ghanaian undercover journalist Anas Arameyew Anas.

Marwa who was set to officiate at the Fifa 2018 World Cup which kicks off on June 14 in Russia was caught on camera receiving $600 (Sh60,000) as a bribe.

articleBody:
Coach Kaka in action. PHOTO/COURTESY

By SPORTS CORRESPONDENT

Hamisi Mohamed popularly known as Coach Kaka has won the international public vote determining the winner of “Future Stars” programme that will see him train with Arsenal Soccer Schools.

This is courtesy of online money transfer firm WorldRemit and their partner of Arsenal FC.

Competing against five other youth football coaches from across Africa, Coach Kaka secured over 35 percent of the votes on https://FutureStars.WorldRemit.com to win the chance to train with coaches from Arsenal Soccer Schools.

Mohamed is Kenya National U-20 Football Assistant Coach. Those who made it to the final shortlist together with Hamsi included Tersia Davids (SA),Innocent Yeboah – Num (Ghana), Ahmed Ali (Somalia),Titus Tongesia (Zimbabwe) and John Adegu Shola (Nigeria)

Mohamed will now to travel to London to attend a customized training programme to support him in building a legacy of positive social impact through football in Kenya.

Mohamed, known locally as Coach Kaka, is one of the founders of Young Talents Soccer Academy, a mixed academy in Embul Bul, Ngong. The academy aims to help children to succeed both on and off the pitch.

“We use the power of football to address social issues, to teach them life skills. We want them to learn to respect themselves, to know the effects of drug abuse, the effects of violence and crime,” Mohamed says.

Coach Kaka during training session. PHOTO/COURTESY

Reflecting the shared values of the two companies, the Future Stars programme was set up by WorldRemit together with Arsenal to acknowledge and reward the valuable contribution of youth coaches to their local communities.

Through the programme, 25 shortlisted coaches have already been granted Arsenal replica shirts for their entire youth squad in recognition of their work.

Andrew Stewart, Managing Director Middle East & Africa at WorldRemit said their business is all about helping their customers’ financial support for their community to go further.

“The work of all the coaches in the Future Stars programme has reinforced our belief in the immense potential of sport to inspire positive change and encouraged us to explore further opportunities to support the communities we serve through sport,” he added.

Steward said they hoped that the “Future Stars” programme will encourage other coaches to follow in the footsteps of the winners example and that this will be only the beginning of a much longer story.”

Back in 1985, in response to social unrest on London estates, Arsenal became one of the first clubs in the UK to set up a dedicated community team in 1985.

The Young Talents academy emerged from similar origins: Hamisi founded the club over 10 years ago to bring young members of his community together following the post-election violence in Kenya.

As Arsenal’s community has grown, so has the impact of Arsenal in the Community’s work and the team now deliver sport, social and education programmes to over 5,000 individuals each week.

Simon McManus of Arsenal Soccer Schools said Arsenal was an example of how the social impact of football can grow from a small local community to an international programme adding that it is inspiring to for them to see how coaches across Africa are using the power of football to support and educate children at the grassroots level and think there is a lot they can also learn from them.

“Both WorldRemit and Arsenal have grown from humble beginnings to become global businesses, credited with transforming our respective sectors. Now we hope that together we can help Hamisi to play a similarly transformational role in Kenya – perhaps even internationally.”

headline: Kenyan veteran science journalist found dead
author: patrick

breadcrumbs.name: Kenyan veteran science journalist found dead

description: Editor and founder of online science journal Rocket Science, Gatonye Gathura. PHOTO/COURTESY By OUR CORRESPONDENT Science journalist and founder of online science journal Rocket Science, Gatonye Ga…
articleBody:
By OUR CORRESPONDENT

Science journalist and founder of online science journal Rocket Science, Gatonye Gathura, has been found dead.

The body of Mr Gathura who went missing on October 26, 2021, was traced to Naivasha Sub-County Referral Hospital morgue after it was booked there as “unknown male adult”.

Police say Gathura’s body was initially found dumped on the Naivasha-Mai Mahiu Road on the day he was reported missing.

The Registrar of Persons is said to have positively identified the body of Gathura today using finger prints.

Naivasha Sub-County Police Commander Samuel Waweru said no identification documents were found on the deceased.

“We are treating his death as murder. We suspect he was killed elsewhere and the body dumped in Naivasha,” Waweru told The Standard.

Gathura’s death brings to 10 the number of journalists in Kenya who have either gone missing or were found dead under mysterious circumstances. Most of the deaths remain unresolved.

Former Nation Media Group (NMG) online editor Antony Kariuki, was found dead in September 2019 following what was said to be a road accident on Outering Road in Nairobi.

Today the murder of Kenya Broadcasting Corporation (KBC) senior editor, Betty Barasa, in her house in Oloolua Ngong on the night of April 7 still remains unresolved.

The whereabouts of Dickson Bosire, popularly known as Bogonko Bosire, the founder of Jackal News and former Nation Media Group legal editor, Albert Muriuki, who disappeared sometime around 2013 remain unknown to date.

The case concerning the killing of former National Land Commission (NLC) Communications Deputy Director Jenifer Wambua whose body was found dumped at Ngong Forest following her abrupt disappearance is still pending before court.

Recent articles by Gathura, who formerly wrote for The Standard and Nation in the past, include Sterilised men protect their women against ovarian cancer – study, that was published on October 19.

Prior to that, he had written two articles on October 16. One was titled Kenyans drop guard as Covid-19 fatigue sets in, and the other titled 20,000 sex workers in Nairobi have mental health issues – study.

During celebrations to mark the International Day to End Impunity and Crimes Against Journalists (IDEA), UNESCO said between 2006 and 2020, more than 1,200 journalists were killed because of their work and nine out of 10 cases, the killers go unpunished.

The UN notes that while journalists killings are the most extreme form of media censorship, journalists are also subjected to countless threats – ranging from kidnapping, torture and other physical attacks to harassment, particularly in the digital sphere.

UNESCO adds that in many cases, threats of violence and attacks against journalists are not properly investigated. This impunity emboldens the perpetrators of the crimes and at the same time has a chilling effect on society, including journalists themselves.

There is also the unresolved cases of former Standard Group Kilifi correspondent Joseph Masha, who collapsed and died moments after meeting a politician, former Weekly Citizen journalist Francis Nyaruri who in 2009 his decapitated body was found two weeks after he disappeared among other cases.

In 2000, Samuel Nduati, a journalist with Royal Media was shot dead by unknown assailants. Nduati had worked on several stories about corruption at the Coffee Board of Kenya.

articleBody:
in KINSHASA

The Executive Secretary of UN Economic Commission for Africa (ECA), Ms Vera Songwe, has told African head of states to take advantage of minerals in their countries to move up the electric vehicles and renewable energy value chain

Ms Songwe was speaking during a business forum to dialogue and identify opportunities and facilitate investments to increase Africa’s share of the battery, electric vehicles and renewable energy value chain that opened in Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) on Wednesday.

The ECA Executive Secretary said Africa is in a good position to profit from the global battery, electric vehicle industry which is projected to be worth 8.8 trillion US dollars by 2025 as it is home to key battery minerals such as cobalt, copper, lithium and manganese.

“The DRC currently supplies 70 percent of the world’s cobalt used in electric vehicle manufacture but captures no more than 3 percent of the battery electric vehicle mining value chain,” Ms Songwe said.

Ms Vera Songwe, UN Economic Commission for Africa (ECA) Executive Secretary talking during the forum. PHOTO/ECA

The ECA Executive Secretary noted that how much transformation will happen to DRC and other African countries currently engaged in producing and selling raw materials will only depend on how fast they move up the value chain adding that an upward shift in the value chain could deliver 25 times more revenue to DRC.

“The DRC Africa Business Forum is where we discuss this possibility of moving the DRC and the rest of Africa up the renewable energy value chain by taking advantage of the African Continental Free Trade Area Agreement (ACFTAA) by building a global African value chain in the battery and electric vehicle supply,” Ms Songwe added.

Authorities want to use the forum to launch Africa’s industrialization process and contribution to mitigating climate change in a way that delivers growth, prosperity and jobs for Africa’s youth and in particular the youth of DRC, according to the ECA.

The two-day DRC Africa Business Forum held in DRC capital Kinshasa and online is convened by the government of the DRC in collaboration with the ECA, Afreximbank, the African Development Bank, the Africa Finance Corporation, the Arab Bank for Economic Development in Africa, the African Legal Support Facility and the UN Global Compact.

headline: Use Diocesan Synod celebrations to embrace those from other faiths Catholics urged
author: patrick

articleBody:
Pope Francis has invited the entire Catholic church to reflect on Synod of Bishops theme “For a synodal church: communion, participation and mission.” PHOTO/VATICAN

By SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT

As Catholics around the world continue to celebrate the Diocesan Synod deliberations the Rt. Rev. Willybard Kitogho Lagho, the Catholic Bishop of Malindi has told Catholics that the event gives them an opportunity to discern and listen to divergent opinions from other faiths.

Rt. Rev. Lagho who was speaking when he announced the start of Malindi Diocese Synod process at St. Joseph Freinademetz (Witu-Kipini) Parish in Tana River County said the upcoming synod is unlike any previous one as it starts with, and involves all the faithful at local churches across the world.

“The Holy Father invites the Churches to dedicate substantial resources to listen to the joys and sorrows of all especially to people who frequently remain in the church periphery like abused teenage girls and mothers, couples in unsolemnized marriages, polygamists, divorced, landless and street families, human trafficked and vulnerable migrants, abandoned babies and elders to mention but a few,” he said.

He added that the Synod in the words of Pope Francis offers Catholics the opportunity to discern and listen to fellow pilgrim including many others who worship differently including atheists.

The Bishop said the theme of the Synod “Communion, Participation, and Mission” entails not only Catholic faithful walking together and listening to one another but above all to the Holy Spirit.

The Vatican has issued a “handbook” or the vademecum for dioceses as part of the global church’s preparation for the 2023 assembly of the Synod of Bishops, discussing the theme, “For a synodal church: communion, participation and mission.”

And the President of the Union of the African Catholic Press (UCAP), Mr George Sunguh, has asked scribes to attend the Synod ceremonies in their respective dioceses and highlight activities being undertaken by Catholic Church.

“I call upon every Catholic communicator and journalist of goodwill from different faith in Africa to attend the ceremonies in their respective dioceses this Sunday and the subsequent activities related to Synod on Synodality over the six months period to spread the news about the process to reach every faithful on the continent,” he said in a statement.

Mr Sungu said the Vatican has published a 12-page working document called the vademecum which can be accessed online vide www.Vademecum-EN-A4.pdf.com for the diocesan phase of the synod which should be read by all seeking to understand the process better.

He noted that the working document is “a tool to facilitate the first phase of listening to and consulting the People of God in the particular Churches” for the diocesan phase of the synod.

“The working document has a set of central questions to be answered by the faithful of which the dioceses will receive and report feedback on to the National Bishops’ Conferences, then to the Symposium of Episcopal Conferences of Africa and Madagascar (SECAM) which will finally send the final document to the Vatican for corroboration,” he said.

Mr Sunguh said the launch of Synod on Synodality in Dioceses 2021in all Catholic Dioceses across the world was a great event for the Catholic Church that required the participation of church followers including journalists.

President of the Union of the African Catholic Press (UCAP) George Sunguh and wife at the Vatican, in Rome moments after attending the Holy Mass celebrated by Pope Francis for the solemn opening of the Synod of Bishops. The dome of Saint Peter’s Basilica built in the 4th century by Emperor Constantine can be seen in the background. PHOTO/GEORGE SUNGUH

“I trust you will all endeavor to successfully deliver on this humble request as the Holy See counts on us for the success of this process by creating awareness amongst the Catholics in Africa as far as possible,” he observed.

Mr Sunguh said the Sunday event follows the successful launch of the Synod on Synodality by Pope Francis on Saturday 9th October 2021 in the Vatican. The process concludes with the XVI Ordinary General Assembly of the Synod of Bishops at the Vatican in October 2023.

headline: Revealed: Kenyatta family wealth abroad
author: patrick
description: President Uhuru Kenyatta and his family members have  assets worth more than $30 million (Ksh 3 billion) abroad. PHOTO/PSCU By WILL FITZGIBBON As President Uhuru Kenyatta mounted a political comeba…
articleBody:
By WILL FITZGIBBON

As President Uhuru Kenyatta mounted a political comeback by campaigning against corruption, his family’s secret fortune was growing offshore, a massive new leak shows.

At his annual State of the Nation address last fall, President Uhuru Kenyatta mounted the podium at Kenya’s Parliament to acknowledge that too many Kenyans live in poverty and too many officials loot the country’s public resources.

The son of Kenya’s first president and leader of one of Africa’s largest economies, the 59-year-old Kenyatta urged lawmakers to join him in fighting corruption and yet again declared “the centrality of transparency, accountability and good governance as the anchors of sustainable development.”

Kenyatta, along with his mother, sisters and brother, have for decades shielded wealth from public scrutiny through foundations and companies in tax havens, including Panama, with assets worth more than $30 million, according to records obtained by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists and shared with more than 600 reporters and media organizations around the world.

The records – from the Panamanian law firm Aleman, Cordero, Galindo & Lee (Alcogal) – show that the family owned at least seven such entities, two registered anonymously in Panama and five in the British Virgin Islands.

The Kenyattas’ offshore wealth, revealed here for the first time, represents part of an estimated half-billion-dollar family fortune amassed in a country where the average annual salary is less than $8,000 a year.

President Kenyatta while reacting to the Pandora Papers story said the expose will lift the veil of secrecy for those who cannot account for their wealth and promised to issue a comprehensive statement when he returns back to Kenya from abroad.

“The Pandora Papers and subsequent follow up audits will lift that veil of secrecy and darkness for those who can not explain their assets or wealth. Thank you,” President Kenyatta said in a statement issued by State House spokesperson Kanze Dena.

The President added that Pandora Papers reports would go a long way in enhancing the financial transparency and openness that is required in Kenya and around the globe.

“The movement of illicit funds, proceeds of crime and corruption thrive in an environment of secrecy and darkness,” the head of state said.

The Kenyatta family began to accumulate much of its offshore wealth while Uhuru Kenyatta was a rising political star. Two offshore companies were created during an investigation into alleged looting of the public treasury during the watch of President Daniel arap Moi, Kenyatta’s former political patron.

Under Kenyan law, the president must provide a list of financial interests to the Ministry of Finance each year. Kenyatta and his family members did not respond to requests for comment, including whether he declared any offshore interests or was required to do so.

Details of the Kenyatta family’s offshore wealth have been brought to light by the Pandora Papers, a collection of more than 11.9 million records from 14 law firms and other service providers based in the United Arab Emirates, the Seychelles, Panama, Singapore and other tax havens.

The investigation has revealed assets of 35 current or former world leaders, including the king of Jordan, the prime minister of the Czech Republic, and Kenyatta’s fellow African leaders Ali Bongo Ondimba of Gabon and Denis Sassou-Nguesso of the Republic of Congo.

Documents show that the expansion of the Kenyattas’ offshore holdings coincided with Uhuru Kenyatta’s political rise, with increasing the layers of secrecy to shield the family’s wealth from scrutiny even as Uhuru solidified his role as a man of the people.

The story of the Kenyatta family fortune, with its various companies and foundations in tax havens, begins with an ambitious tribal scion who would become one of post-colonial Africa’s most iconic leaders: Jomo Kenyatta.

Uhuru Kenyatta’s father was born Kamau Ngengi circa 1894 in the fertile Central Highlands of what was then known as British East Africa. Kamau’s father was a village chief in the powerful Kikuyu tribe, in a country where tribal affiliation often determines the outcome of elections.

Educated at a Christian mission school, the young Kamau signaled his ambitions by taking the name Jomo Kenyatta, a local word for “burning spear.”

At the start of the 20th century, a British colonial government tightened its grip on the region’s non-white population. A “hut tax” was imposed on people with little or no money, many of whom depended on their crops and livestock for survival. Some were driven to prostitution or consigned to forced labor.

Like many of his contemporaries, Jomo Kenyatta rebelled.

“Nothing is more important than a correct grasp of the question of land tenure,” Kenyatta wrote in 1938, while attending university in London. “For it is the key to the people’s life.”

When he left prison nearly nine years later, Jomo took charge of independence negotiations, and, in 1963, Kenya gained independence, with Kenyatta as prime minister. In 1964, he became the country’s first president, and he presided over an economic boom that burnished the country’s reputation as a post-colonial model.

But instead of building democracy, Kenyatta turned the fledgling nation into a one-party state marked by arbitrary detention, torture and political assassination. Promised land reform became a land grab: Kenyans found that property had simply changed hands from European elites to Kenyatta cronies.

headline: UN’s visionary feminist plan for sustainability and social justice
author: patrick

breadcrumbs.name: UN’s visionary feminist plan for sustainability and social justice

description: UN Women are helping women farmers in Guinea with new opportunities to generate income and improve community life. PHOTO/UN WOMEN/JOE SAADE By PATRICK MAYOYO The United Nations has come up with a “…
articleBody:
By PATRICK MAYOYO

The United Nations has come up with a “Feminist plan” that provides a visionary but practical roadmap for putting gender equality, social justice, and sustainability at the centre of recovery and transformation from COVID-19 pandemic impacts.

The UN Women’s new “Feminist plan” maps the ambitious and transformative policies—on livelihoods, care, and the environment—that are needed to build a more equal and sustainable future.

To get there, it calls for context-specific policy pathways, tailored political strategies, and financing. The plan identifies key levers that can create change and the actors at global, national, and local levels that need to take action to move towards this vision.

The report says since COVID-19 was declared a pandemic, 18 months ago, it has claimed more than 4 million lives , destroyed countless livelihoods and forced the global economy to its knees and with an end still out of sight, the crisis has already taken a disproportionate toll on women and girls.

“As countries locked down, rates of domestic abuse spiralled upwards. With more girls out of school, child marriage and female genital mutilation will likely rise. As the health crisis morphed into a full-blown economic recession, women bore the brunt of job losses, seeing their economic autonomy stifled and their poverty risk rise,” the report notes.

UN Women’s Beyond COVID-19: A Feminist Plan for Sustainability and Social Justice, draws on the latest data, analysis, and input from more than 100 global experts to provide concrete pathways for putting gender equality, environmental sustainability, and social justice at the centre of global development efforts.

In the first UN plan of its kind, the report details how the COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated pre-existing gender inequalities and laid bare weaknesses in the already fragile global care economy.

“Globally, in 2019 and 2020, women lost 54 million jobs, and even before the pandemic, they took on three times as much unpaid care work as men”, UN Women says.

UN Women says by the end of 2021, men’s jobs will have recovered, but there will still be 13 million fewer women in employment, adding that women are disproportionately impacted by environmental degradation while also being left out of decision-making around policy and financing to address climate change.

To address these intersecting crises, UN Women is calling for better policy, action and investment, including in the care economy and social infrastructure, such as creating jobs and increasing support for unpaid caregivers.

The report maintains that public investments in care services could create 40 to 60 per cent more jobs than the same investments in construction.

Despite having been on the frontlines of the COVID-19 response, making up 70 per cent of healthcare workers globally, the roadmap notes that women currently hold only 24 percent of seats on COVID-19 taskforces that have coordinated the policy response around the world.

UN Women adds that in 2018-19, women’s rights organizations received only one per cent of all aid allocated by the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) to gender equality, amounting to only a tiny fraction of total aid.

The report says to finance the envisaged measures, transformative macroeconomic policies – including progressive taxes and, especially for low-income countries, global cooperation and debt relief – are urgently needed.
